titleInfo.title: Relationships among Neuroticism Facets, Negative Career Thoughts, and Congruence in College Students

name.namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.abstract: The present study examined the relationships among neuroticism facets, three types of negative career thoughts, and congruence in a sample of 180 college students enrolled in a career development course. Bivariate correlations and multiple regression analyses revealed that the neuroticism facets most strongly associated with dysfunctional career thinking were facets 3 (depression) and 6 (vulnerability), both of which predicted higher scores on the decision-making confusion (DMC) and external conflict (EC) subscales of the Career Thoughts Inventory (CTI). Neuroticism facet 1 (anxiety) emerged as an inverse predictor of DMC, suggesting that anxiety may protect against this type of dysfunctional career thinking. This finding contributes to a limited but growing body of research on beneficial aspects of neuroticism. The neuroticism facet of vulnerability displayed a significant, negative correlation with one congruence index. However, neuroticism facets and negative career thoughts did not significantly predict congruence in multiple regression analyses, suggesting that negative emotionality and dysfunctional career thinking do not necessarily impair students' ability to identify career paths that align with their vocational interests. Multiple regression analyses also showed that holding a minoritized racial identity predicted lower scores on the commitment anxiety (CA) and EC subscales of the CTI, meaning that students from marginalized racial groups experienced fewer of these negative career thoughts. However, holding a minoritized racial identity also predicted less alignment between students' activities of interest and their skills, as did identifying as cisgender male. Finally, the limited overlap observed among the five congruence indices calculated in this study demonstrates the importance of considering multiple data generated by the Self-Directed Search (SDS) when assessing a college student's level of congruence and points to the continued need for research regarding the best ways to operationalize this construct. Implications for theory, practice, research, test development, and education/training are discussed. This exploratory study provides a foundation for future investigations into how personality facets impact college students' metacognitive skills, occupational choice, and career outcomes.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Debra Osborn, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; V. Casey Dozier, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Lenore McWey, University Representative; Deborah Ebener, Committee Member; Martin Swanbrow Becker, Committee Member.
